On 8/25/06, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
>
>
> I work this=
 way: either I tolerate test failures or I don't. I tolerate
> test failure=
s for customer tests, but not for programmer tests. I've
> never wanted to =
tolerate "a few" failures, for any value of "a few" in
> code that I commit=
ted to source control.


As I mentioned earlier, there are categories of te=
sts that tolerate what I
call "partial failures", the best example being se=
nding packets over an
unreliable network or a protocol that doesn't guarant=
ee delivery (e.g. UDP),
or cross-talk packets in a clustered application, o=
r simply sending SMS
messages, to name a few examples.

Of course, there is=
 also the case where you know that a few tests are broken
and they need to =
remain so for a certain period of time, but that's probably
a slightly diff=
erent topic.

-- 
C=E9dric
http://testng.org
